Social Spending

Max Roser [cite]
OWID presents work from many different people and organizations. When citing this entry, please also cite the original data source. This entry can be cited as:

Max Roser (2016) – ‘Social Spending’. Published online at OurWorldInData.org. Retrieved from: https://ourworldindata.org/social-spending/ [Online Resource]

 

# Empirical View

# Tax-based social spending (as % of gross national product) in the early modern countries, 18th & 19th century – Lindert (2004)1

# Public social spending in percentage of GDP, 1960-2012 – OECD5

# Public social expenditure by broad social policy area in percentage of GDP, 2003 – OECD8

# Data Sources

# Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Social Expenditure Database
  • Data: Statistics on public and private social expenditure and net social spending indicators
  • Geographical coverage: 34 OECD countries
  • Time span: 1980-2011 and estimates for 2012-2014
  • Available at: Online here

Footnotes

  1. The source of the data is Table 1.1 in Lindert (2004) – Growing Public: Social Spending and Economic Growth since the Eighteenth Century: Vol. 1 – The Story. Cambridge University Press.

    Public education includes education from primary to university education. The poor relief ﬁgure is for 1840–47.

  2. The data is taken from Lindert (2004) – Growing Public: Social Spending and Economic Growth since the Eighteenth Century: Vol. 1 – The Story. Cambridge University Press.

    For Australia and Spain it is known to be 0 until 1900. For Canada it is 0 until 1910 and for Greece and Italy it is 0 until 1920. Lindert includes two values for 1980 (OECD old and OECD new). Here I show OECD new only to make comparison with latest observations possible.

  3. Lindert (2004) – Growing Public: Social Spending and Economic Growth since the Eighteenth Century: Vol. 1 – The Story. Cambridge University Press.

    Notes: * is the series OECD new; ” is the series OECD old.

    0 = known to be zero; blank = not yet a sovereign state; . . =known to be positive, but number unavailable.

    “Germany” is West Germany only for 1960–1990. For Greece “1995” is actually 1993.

  4. Lindert (2004) – Growing Public: Social Spending and Economic Growth since the Eighteenth Century: Vol. 1 – The Story. Cambridge University Press.

  5. The source is the OECD here.

    According to the source this data is ‘based on detailed data for 1960-2009; national aggregates for 2010-2011 and estimates for 2012’.

  6. The source is the OECD here.

  7. The source is the OECD here.

  8. The source is the OECD here. 

Our World in Data

Our World in Data is an online publication by Max Roser which explores the development of human living conditions at a global scale. Our work is licensed under CC BY-SA and freely usable by everyone (including journalists, authors, bloggers, lecturers, or educators).

We are supported by the generous donations of readers. Without these donations our work would not be possible. Thank you!

OWID is developed at the Oxford Martin School:

OWID is also supported by INET Oxford:

And the Nuffield Foundation:

The Nuffield Foundation is an endowed charitable trust that aims to improve social well-being in the widest sense. It has funded this project, but the views expressed are those of the authors and not necessarily those of the foundation.
